Remember that there is no field where there has not been a tremendous
amount of authoritative research done, and where facts are available*
There is drama, achievement by ordinary people, interesting personali¬
ties, community success stories, "how to" pieces galore, personal experience
pieces, crusading editorials and articles of expose—and even humor. All
interesting possibilities on their own, but also of tremendous importance
to America's families and future*
FOR EDITORS AND SAFETY PUBLECISTS: Don't neglect the publications
in the Business and Industrial fields. House organs, those with the most
limited or restricted appeal, have a tremendous circulation* Publicists
should feed these editors with material of various aspects of their special
interests. Editor? of such publications should be reminded that, since
they are designed and edited to serve industry or the business house that
produces them, it is to management's immense benefit that workers be made
as safety-minded while off the job as when on it.
THE PLEDGE: Since this is designed more for local than national
campaigns, not many of the larger magazines of general circulation can use
it—except perhaps as basis for a story on how some community licked a
tough situation through its use, and thus publicize the idea for adoption
by other communities. The exception: House organs, trade journals, and
others addressed to a limited and restricted audience can employ it to
establish a plant record, etc.
SUGGESTION: A special pledge be devised for the media group, pledging
the magazines cooperation (likewise the radio station's, newspaper's, etc.)
in the Crusade for Safety. Upon receipt of which a Certificate of Merit
(or of Recognition or Appreciation) be sent the journal, paper, or station
for framing and hanging on the wall—as a steady reminder to keep up the
good work of plugging safety.
Respectfully submitted, CLARENCE HAIL, Chairman
Outdoor Advertising Committee
The Outdoor Advertisers, meeting as a committee of the media group
of the White House Conference on Highway Safety, recommends:
1. That the Outdoor Advertising medium expand its present support
of the traffic safety public information campaign.
2. That State and local councils of all media be established, where
they do not exist, for the purpose of coordinating traffic safety public
information activities.
3. That a national organization, such as the Advertising Council,
be designated as the facility to provide the local outdoor advertising
companies, a uniform national public information program on traffic safety.
